{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3547735,"name":"mikets","username":"mikets","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mikets/{size}/4625_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-04T23:53:57.060Z","cooked":"

We started to get the “not enough space” error lately when we started to play with Vision. We are using Photon Vision on an OrangePi. Generally, OpenCV allocates Mats natively in C++ that may cause “out of memory” error in Java if you don’t explicitly release the Mats afterwards. But we are not running OpenCV pipeline in our code, the OpenCV code is running on OrangePi. We are simply doing AprilTag detection using the provided OrangePi image. There is no custom code. So, I am not certain who’s consuming so much memory on the RIO. If we disable Photon Vision in our code, the problem doesn’t repro. We have two cameras running PhotonVision. If we enable both of them, the RIO will crash almost immediately with the “memory error” and will go into endless reboot. If we just enable one camera, we will probably get a few minutes time before it crashes.

BTW, I did search the forums for this error. It seems it happened about a year ago but that has nothing to do with Vision and seems to say a new version of WPILib had fixed it. So, I would expect this is a new problem.

If you’re running on a roboRIO 1, this is fairly common. See the below documentation page for some solution options.

FIRST Robotics Competition Documentation

Java Garbage Collection

Java garbage collection is the process of automatically managing memory for Java objects. The Java Virtual Machine (JVM) is responsible for creating and destroying objects, and the garbage collecto...

Have you tried profiling to see what is using memory?

Yes, this is a RIO2. Interestingly, we loaded the same code to last season’s robot and just disabling all upper subsystems leaving only drive base and vision code active, the problem did not repro. So, it seems to rule out our code issue. Furthermore, we have a spare brand new RIO2. I quickly prep’d the new RIO with the latest image and loaded our code on it. I even stole the same OrangePi from the competition robot and connected it to the new RIO and the problem didn’t repro. Now, I am comparing what else is different from this setup with our competition robot. The differences are: RoboRIO and the two cameras. Tomorrow, I am going to disable all subsystems on the competition robot to make sure it’s equivalent to the test setup code wise. I am also planning to steal the two cameras from the competition robot and test the setup again. If the problem is still not repro, then the only difference is the RoboRIO. If that’s the case, my last thing to do is to re-image the RoboRIO on the competition robot to see if that will make any difference.

Our competition is this weekend. We are running out of time, so I am trying something easy to rule things out. I will certainly go that route if those failed to identify the culprit.

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-03-05T07:24:54.018Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":88,"readers_count":87,"score":17.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494263,"topic_slug":"openjdk-client-vm-warning-info-os-commit-memory-0xb42f7000-32768-1-failed-error-not-enough-space-errno-12","display_username":"mikets","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":65,"username":"Joe_Ross","name":"Joe Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13461,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/openjdk-client-vm-warning-info-os-commit-memory-0xb42f7000-32768-1-failed-error-not-enough-space-errno-12/494263/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3548190,"name":"Peter Johnson","username":"Peter_Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T14:38:33.717Z","cooked":"

From your original problem description, it sounds like there’s a leak in the code that’s processing the data from PhotonVision, since if you turn one or both of those off, the problem slows down or goes away. So I’d start by carefully inspecting that code (and anything it provides data to, like a pose estimator) for anything that retains information (eg a queue) and if there are any code paths that don’t cap the size or clear it. This is an educated guess based on your problem description, profiling would confirm it.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-03-05T14:40:23.988Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":83,"readers_count":82,"score":26.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494263,"topic_slug":"openjdk-client-vm-warning-info-os-commit-memory-0xb42f7000-32768-1-failed-error-not-enough-space-errno-12","display_username":"Peter Johnson","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13575,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Volunteer WPILib Developer, CSA"},"post_url":"/t/openjdk-client-vm-warning-info-os-commit-memory-0xb42f7000-32768-1-failed-error-not-enough-space-errno-12/494263/8","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3548464,"name":"mikets","username":"mikets","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mikets/{size}/4625_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T18:37:23.107Z","cooked":"

I’ll look into that today, but doesn’t Java’s memory allocation get reclaimed automatically by the garbage collector?

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-03-05T18:37:23.107Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":8,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":58,"readers_count":57,"score":16.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494263,"topic_slug":"openjdk-client-vm-warning-info-os-commit-memory-0xb42f7000-32768-1-failed-error-not-enough-space-errno-12","display_username":"mikets","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13575,"username":"Peter_Johnson","name":"Peter Johnson","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/peter_johnson/{size}/10417_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":13461,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/openjdk-client-vm-warning-info-os-commit-memory-0xb42f7000-32768-1-failed-error-not-enough-space-errno-12/494263/9","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3548659,"name":"Joe Ross","username":"Joe_Ross","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/joe_ross/{size}/37_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-05T21:20:26.038Z","cooked":"

Yes, but not immediately. So your memory usage could be growing faster then the garbage collector can release it.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":30,"updated_at":"2025-03-05T21:20:26.038Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":53,"readers_count":52,"score":15.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":494263,"topic_slug":"openjdk-client-vm-warning-info-os-commit-memory-0xb42f7000-32768-1-failed-error-not-enough-space-errno-12","display_username":"Joe Ross","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":13461,"username":"mikets","name":"mikets","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mikets/{size}/4625_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":65,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/openjdk-client-vm-warning-info-os-commit-memory-0xb42f7000-32768-1-failed-error-not-enough-space-errno-12/494263/10","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3549667,"name":"mikets","username":"mikets","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mikets/{size}/4625_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-06T19:38:51.795Z","cooked":"

I have read the WPILib doc about diagnosing “out of memory” error. It suggested to add the following to build.gradle to automatically do a heap dump to a file. I pushed this build to the robot and the robot rebooted numerous times because of the out-of-memory error but I can’t locate the heap dump file with WinSCP. I have followed the recommendation of plugging in a 64GB USB thumb drive into the USB A connector on the RIO. The Thumb Drive is formatted as exFAT. I even plugged the drive to my laptop and it’s empty. Would you tell me how I can locate the file?
frcJava(getArtifactTypeClass(‘FRCJavaArtifact’)) {
// // Enable VisualVM connection
// jvmArgs.add(“-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote=true”)
// jvmArgs.add(“-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.port=1198”)
// jvmArgs.add(“-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.local.only=false”)
// jvmArgs.add(“-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.ssl=false”)
// jvmArgs.add(“-Dcom.sun.management.jmxremote.authenticate=false”)
// jvmArgs.add(“-Djava.rmi.server.hostname=10.4.92.2”)

                // Enable automatic heap dumps on OutOfMemoryError
                // Note: the heap dump path here is a path on a USB flash drive, see below
                jvmArgs.add("-XX:+HeapDumpOnOutOfMemoryError")
                jvmArgs.add("-XX:HeapDumpPath=/u/frc-usercode.hprof")
            }

ExFAT isn’t supported, only FAT32.

I think the issue you’re having is that the drive is mounted at exFAT - the rio only supports FAT32. Check this page in the DogLog docs for info on how to format it:

DogLog Docs

Formatting a USB drive

Learn how to format a USB drive to use with DogLog.

I would check the /u directory, since that’s what you pointed it to in the Gradle setup. If a USB drive is connected, it’s automatically mounted to /u.

There are some unusual reported classes though—what are you using from org.apache.commons.math3?
